ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Some basic stats knowledge, pretty much AP Stats + poisson distributions and learning how to use minitab.
Basic overview of statistical principles and data analysis.
Probability, linear regression, proper experiment setup and basic data analysis
I learned a lot of intro statistical knowledge that I had not previously had, and how to apply it in situations I might encounter in my social science degree.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think as is, it can't be improved just due to the format. Serves as a really good intro to stats, if you have never taken AP stats before, you should probably take this before other S&DS classes, but if you've taken AP stats it's a total waste of time (unless you want a half-credit gut like I did).

This is a fantastic course. I don't have any weaknesses to suggest. 
Strengths include clear lectures & lecture slides, an abundance of office hours for help with Psets and concepts, and active ed discussion.

The flexibility of the course is great, but could leave you feeling disconnected from the course (kinda on the student though since there are an abundance of office hours). Sometimes the live lectures moved at a different pace from recorded. Well organized!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Would recommend if you've either not taken AP stats or want a gut .5 credit.

Yes! Statistics is not the most riveting subject, but will be useful to practically any field you go into so I think it is worth it. This is a very well taught course, and unlike many of the "intro" courses I've encountered, ACTUALLY assumes no prior knowledge of the subject and goes over all of the details of even basic concepts.
Yes, it is great to have exposure to this subject and was made accessible.
